trouble.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Recent stock market losses point to trouble ahead.
We’re having a lot of trouble with the new computer system.
trouble.translation[0].definitions[1].de: used when saying what is bad about a person or situation or what causes problems
trouble.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The trouble with you is that you don’t listen.
The trouble is there are too many people and not enough places.
But no one ever remembers – that’s the trouble.
You never think, that’s your trouble.
trouble.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: If the kids start to cause trouble, ask them to move on.
A handful of people came looking for trouble.
If you start any trouble, you’ll regret it.
There was crowd trouble before the match.
trouble.translation[0].definitions[3].de: problems in your life which you are worried about
trouble.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: He poured out all his troubles to me  (=told me all about his problems).
trouble.translation[0].definitions[4].de: an amount of effort and time that is needed to do something
trouble.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: They’ve obviously gone to a lot of trouble to arrange everything.
I find that making my own clothes is more trouble than it’s worth (=takes too much time and effort).
The teacher took the trouble to learn all our names on the first day.
take the trouble to do something
If you’d asked me first, I could have saved you the trouble.
save somebody the trouble (of doing something)
trouble.translation[0].definitions[5].de: a problem that you have with your health
trouble.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: He has trouble with his breathing.
trouble.translation[0].definitions[6].de: when something is wrong with a machine, vehicle, or system
trouble.translation[0].definitions[6].ex: He had to retire from the race because of trouble with the gearbox.
trouble.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: have trouble
He is having trouble getting his message across to the voters.
have no trouble
We had no trouble finding her house.
cause trouble
I hope the delay hasn’t caused you any trouble.
there is trouble
There was some trouble at her office, but she didn’t say what it was.
mean/spell trouble
They are now much more competitive, which can only spell trouble for their rivals.
be asking for trouble
It’s asking for trouble to wear high-heeled shoes on a long walk.
avoid trouble
We avoid trouble by planning carefully.
big/great trouble
High interest rates spell big trouble for homeowners.
terrible trouble
I’ve been having terrible trouble sleeping.
endless trouble
They had endless trouble with the water supply.
serious trouble
I was having serious trouble knowing where to begin.
teething troubles
There were a lot of teething troubles in the first year.
what the trouble is
A couple of nurses rushed into the room to see what the trouble was.
without any/much trouble
The work was carried out without any trouble.
trouble.translation[0].note_box[1].items: Trouble  is usually used as an uncountable noun    Trouble is not used with ‘a’
Are you having trouble with your car?
Are you having a trouble with your car?
The plural form troubles is used when talking about worries or bad experiences that someone has
Tell me about all your troubles
trouble.translation[1].definitions[0].de: if a problem troubles you, it makes you feel worried or upset
trouble.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: There is one thing that’s been troubling me.
They have been deeply troubled by the allegations.
trouble.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to say something or ask someone to do something which may use or waste their time or upset them
trouble.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: I promise not to trouble you again.
I don’t want to trouble the doctor with it.
I won’t trouble you with the details.
trouble.translation[1].definitions[2].de: if a medical problem troubles you, it causes you pain or problems
trouble.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: He is still being troubled by an ankle injury.
trouble.translation[1].definitions[3].de: to cause someone problems or difficulties
trouble.translation[1].definitions[3].ex: They look good enough to trouble most teams in the competition.
